arm_group.arm_group_label: Horizontal adduction stretch without scapular stabilization
arm_group.description: Scapular stabilization is not provided during a manual horizontal adduction stretch of the shoulder.  Each stretch is held for 25 seconds and repeated for a total of 3 times.
Scapular stabilization is provided during a manual horizontal adduction stretch of the shoulder.  Each stretch is held for 25 seconds and repeated for a total of 3 times.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine if stabilizing the scapula (shoulder blade) during
      a common shoulder stretch is more effective at improving shoulder range of motion than not
      stabilizing the scapula.  Investigators hypothesize that scapular stabilization during
      horizontal adduction stretching will demonstrate greater gains in shoulder range of motion
      than stretching without scapular stabilization.

clinical_study.brief_title: Scapular Stabilization During Manual Horizontal Adduction Stretches and Its Effect on Increasing Posterior Shoulder Flexibility

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  athletes with at least two years of volleyball experience

          -  athletes with no current shoulder pain

          -  athletes between the ages of 15 and 21

          -  athletes with a 10 degree or greater difference in internal rotation between
             shoulders

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  athletes currently experiencing shoulder pain

          -  athletes having less than two years of volleyball experience

          -  athletes not meting inclusion criteria

intervention.description: Scapular is stabilized during manual horizontal adduction stretch
intervention.intervention_name: horizontal adduction stretch with scapular stabilization

intervention.arm_group_label: Horizontal adduction stretch without scapular stabilization
intervention.description: Scapula stabilization is not performed during horizontal adduction stretch
intervention.intervention_name: Horizontal adduction stretch without scapular stabilization

clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Scapular Stabilization During Horizontal Adduction Stretching on Passive Internal Rotation and Posterior Shoulder Tightness in Young Female Volleyball Athletes.

overall_official.affiliation: Nova Southeastern University and Southeastern Orthopedics Sports Medicine and Shoulder Center

primary_outcome.description: An inclinometer is used to measure posterior shoulder tightness.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from  baseline posterior shoulder tightness to immediately following manual stretching.  The baseline is measured, followed by 3 stretches held for 25 seconds and then the follow up measure is taken.  This is the conclusion of this measure.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Director of Rehabilitation at Southeastern Orthopedics Sports Medicine and Shoulder Center

secondary_outcome.description: An inclinometer is used to measure internal rotation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from  baseline internal rotation to immediately following manual stretching.  The baseline is measured, followed by 3 stretches held for 25 seconds and then the follow up measure is taken.  This is the conclusion of this measure.

collaborator.agency: Southeastern Orthopedics Sports Medicine and Shoulder Center

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator), Primary Purpose: Prevention
